ii
Resumo
O nosso planeta está a sofrer uma inquestionável mudança climática, cada vez mais acentuada,
atribuída a ações antropogénicas. Devido ao constante crescimento populacional e diante dos novos
desenvolvimentos tecnológicos tem-se observado uma intensificação de atividades humanas com
consequências nocivas para a sustentabilidade do Sistema Terrestre. O aumento contínuo da emissão de
gases que contribuem para o efeito de estufa tem como fonte principal a queima de combustíveis fósseis
(CO2), a agricultura intensiva (CH4) e o emprego de gases fluorados industriais. O fenómeno do
aquecimento global é considerado uma das maiores ameaças ambientais do século XXI. As alterações
climáticas, impulsionadas pelas atividades antropogénicas, terão consequências transversais a várias
áreas da sociedade particularmente na economia, na saúde e no ambiente, sendo urgente medidas
mitigadoras para que estes impactos não se agravem nas próximas décadas. De acordo com os cenários
previstos, é muito provável que no futuro para além do aumento da temperatura média global, ocorra
um aumento do nível médio do mar e um incremento na frequência e duração de fenómenos climáticos
extremos, incluindo secas, cheias, precipitação intensa e ondas de calor. Consequentemente, as
alterações climáticas irão afetar profundamente os ecossistemas a nível global, em especial os
ecossistemas costeiros.
Os Estuários são zonas húmidas costeiras muito ricas do ponto de vista biológico, onde ocorre
grande mistura de água doce e água salgada que facilita a acumulação de sedimentos, nomeadamente
nas zonas de sapal. As zonas estuarinas, devido à sua localização privilegiada e riqueza biológica, têm
atraído, desde sempre, a população humana para as suas margens, servindo de localização para as
maiores metrópoles do mundo. As ações antrópicas que, consequentemente, desde há várias décadas,
estas regiões têm conhecido, de que são exemplos a exploração excessiva de recursos haliêuticos, o
lançamento de resíduos sólidos, a eutrofização causada pela entrada de matéria orgânica, a dragagem e
a introdução de espécies invasoras, têm causado impactos negativos. Os sapais têm grande interesse do
ponto de vista económico, social e ecológico, prestando serviços de proteção à erosão costeira e à subida
do nível do mar, estabilização de sedimentos, habitat para uma diversa variedade de espécies,
purificação e retenção de água, remoção e transformação de nutrientes, oportunidades educacionais e
recreativas, entre outros, pelo que a sua conservação tem, pois, elevada importância. As plantas de sapal,
nomeadamente plantas halófitas, são de um modo geral, tal como o nome indica, extremamente
resistentes a elevadas concentrações de sal, e a vários stresses ambientais, tais como contaminação de
metais pesados, inundações e eventos térmicos extremos. Contudo, apesar da resiliência demonstrada
por estas plantas, as alterações climáticas acopladas com as pressões antrópicas terão um profundo
impacto nos sapais costeiros. A resistência e a tolerância das plantas halófitas varia consoante a espécie
e o tipo de stress, ou seja, quando expostas a determinados cenários as espécies mais resistentes às novas
condições adquirem vantagem em relação às outras, o que poderá alterar a distribuição e frequências
das espécies dentro do sapal.
No entanto, espécies com uma ampla distribuição geográfica e uma grande capacidade de
adaptação e aclimatação revelam, normalmente, variações morfológicas, fenológicas e fisiológicas entre
populações, de acordo com os condicionamentos locais. Estas plantas podem apresentar, desta forma,
tolerância cruzada o que permite aumentar a resistência a uma gama de diferentes stresses após a
exposição a um específico stress. Adicionalmente, as plantas, devido à heterogeneidade ambiental,
podem exibir variações intraespecíficas que iram influenciar a maneira como cada população irá
responder a futuras alterações climáticas. Deste modo, as consequências diretas das mudanças climáticas
podem ter diferentes impactos nas plantas de sapal que apresentam variações intraespecíficas, podendo
afetar, de diferente modo, a estrutura e função destas comunidades.
iii
Esta tese tem como principais objetivos investigar de que modo, desde logo, o pré-
condicionamento abiótico encontrado em diferentes populações de halófitas vai influenciar as suas
respostas ecofisiológicas a stresses abióticos, conjeturados pelas previsões locais das alterações
climáticas, e, ainda, se estas apresentam uma tolerância cruzada suficientemente significativa de modo
a determinar a maneira como o sapal irá evoluir e que consequências ecológicas que poderá sofrer.
Mais concretamente, pretendeu-se compreender as consequências das variações
intraespecíficas, induzidas por pré-condicionamento, apresentadas pelas populações de duas espécies de
halófitas com uma ampla distribuição geográfica, a C3 Halimione portulacoides e a invasora C4 Spartina
patens, que colonizam dois sapais vizinhos no estuário do Tejo com diferentes níveis de metais pesados,
numa primeira abordagem, face a um aumento de temperatura e numa segunda abordagem, face a um
aumento de salinidade.
O estudo da influencia da tolerância cruzada ao stress de calor constituiu a primeira abordagem
para compreender as variações ecofisiológicas nas respostas das populações pré-condicionadas e não
pré-condicionadas a metais pesados de H. portulacoides e S. patens a eventos de calor. Para tal e segundo
o “Intergovernmental Panel on Climatic Change”, que indica, com grande certeza, que a frequência e a
intensidade dos eventos de calor aumentarão devido ao fenómeno do aquecimento global, as plantas
foram expostas a um tratamento de calor durante uma semana e, seguidamente, as suas respostas
fisiológicas e bioquímicas foram profundamente analisadas. De acordo com os resultados apresentados
na tese, obtidos através de medições fotobiológicas, de atividade enzimática e ocorrência de peroxidação
lipídica, acoplando com as analises aos pigmentos e ácidos gordos, a tolerância cruzada indica que o
pré-condicionamento a metais pesados influencia significativamente os mecanismos de tolerância ao
stress térmico das plantas halófitas. Constatou-se que H. portulacoides pré-condicionado por metais
pesados, por tolerância cruzada, apresenta maior resistência ao stress de calor que o H. portulacoides
do sapal não contaminado, por outro lado S. patens, quando pré-condicionada por metais pesados, exibe
uma pior performance na presença deste stress.
Posteriormente estudou-se a influencia do pré-condicionamento a metais pesados na tolerância
a aumentos de salinidades em duas populações de H. portulacoides e S. patens. A salinidade devido às
alterações climáticas, acabará por crescer em consequência do aumento de eventos de tempestade, de
ondas de maré e o do nível médio do mar. Ao contrario da maioria das plantas, as halófitas podem viver
e prosperar em solos com salinidades até 855 mM, contudo as espécies halófitas têm respostas dispares
à mesma salinidade, abrangendo espécies cujo desempenho óptimo ocorre em ambientes sem sal até
espécies onde ambientes altamente salinos são ideais. Sendo assim, indivíduos das populações de H.
portulacoides e S. patens dos sapais referidos anteriormente foram expostos a uma variedade de
salinidades (0 mM NaCl, 400 mM NaCl, 800 mM NaCl) durante uma semana e logo após o tratamento
foram analisadas fisiológica e bioquimicamente. Os resultados, adquiridos através dos mesmos métodos
usados no estudo anterior, mostram que o pré-condicionamento de metais pesados tem um papel
significativo na forma como as plantas responderam aos stresses. Através disso, verificou-se que S.
patens pré-condicionado a metais pesados apresentou um maior fitness aos ambientes salinos,
comparando com a população do sapal não contaminado, no entanto H. portulacoides manifestou uma
complexa influência não linear à tolerância cruzada, uma vez que exibiu, quando pré-condicionado, uma
performance pior quando exposto a 400 mM NaCl enquanto a 800 mM NaCl apresentou um melhor
desempenho.
Em resumo, é evidente que a halotolerância e a termotolerância das plantas anteriormente
estudadas estão claramente interligadas com o seu pré-condicionamento, apresentando uma tolerância
cruzada significativa, que vai ter um potencial impacto ecológico e poderá influenciar a forma como
dois sapais vizinhos irão evoluir. Assim sendo, assumindo que as condições a que as plantas foram
expostas representam as condições que, fruto das alterações climáticas, existirão no futuro, podemos
constatar que o sapal contaminado poderá ser mais resistente à invasão por parte do S. patens do que o
iv
sapal não-contaminado, quando impactados por eventos de calor e evidencia, também, ser em geral mais
resiliente ao aumento de salinidade.
Em conclusão, os resultados deste estudo mostram que o pré-condicionamento induz uma
complexa variação intraespecífica nos mecanismos de tolerância aos stresses abióticos. Esta variação
intraespecífica pode afetar significativamente a maneira como as comunidades de sapais irão evoluir no
futuro, podendo influenciar, a estrutura e função de cada sapal. Assim, este estudo contribuiu com
informação relevante para o conhecimento de processos ecofisiológicos e pode ser pertinente para
modelar e prever possível cenários das mudanças climáticas nos sapais, assim como pode ter interesse
para uma gestão de ações de conservação mais eficiente e especificas para cada sapal.
Palavras-chave: Halimione portulacoides, Spartina patens, variação intraespecífica, sapal de
Alcochete, sapal do Rosário.
v
Abstract
Climate change is having an increasing effect worldwide, causing weighty disturbances
in virtually all ecosystems thru arising abiotic variations. Salt marshes ecosystems, although highly
resilient, are no exception to the climate shift consequences. Considering halophyte communities
resistence and tolerance to abiotic alterations, climate change still makes them vulnerable to dire
consequences in their productivity, ending up upsetting the distribution and biodiversity of marsh
vegetation, compromising their economic, social and ecological services and unique role as the "Kidneys
of the planet".
This project aimed to determine heavy metal cross-tolerance thru pre-conditioning to abiotic
stresses in halophyte plants. Analyzing the influence that adaptations to local conditions have in
tolerance and resistance mechanisms and if this will be relevant in the stress response to the abiotic
variations predicted in the future climate change and what could this mean for the shifting ecosystems.
For this, it was studied the physiological responses to abiotic stresses in two different populations of the
wide spread halophyte species, the native C3 Halimione portulacoides and the invasive C4 Spartina
patens, from nearby salt marshes in the Tagus estuary, with the major difference between them being
heavy metal soil content.
Firstly, on the basis that the frequency and intensity of warming events will rise, in duration and
frequency, due to global warming, the halophyte plant groups where exposed to a warming event and
then analyzed photobiologically and biochemically. The cross-tolerance results shown that heavy metal
pre-condition enhanced the heat resistance mechanisms in H. portulacoides and worsened S. patens
ability to cope with these changes, when compared to their non-pre-conditioned counterparts. This can
have important consequences in the way the non-contaminated and heavy metal contaminated salt
marshes will react to environmental changes, that can lead to possibly different ecological consequences.
Considering the predicted climate change scenarios, it can be claimed that the contaminated marsh can
be more resistant to invasion than the pristine marshes, were the warming events will benefit the exotic
S. patens in relation to the native H. portulacoides.
Secondly and taking in to consideration that land salinization is an increasing problem around
the world and climate change will intensify this phenomenon especially in coastal lands, due to tidal
surges, storm surges and sea level rise coupled with the increasing evaporation because of global
warming, the halophyte species from both the studied salt marshes were exposed to a variety of salt
treatments. When analyzed, the results exposed a noteworthy influence that the heavy metal pre-
conditioned has in the salinity stress responses. In view of the future changes, it can be argued that
heavy metal contaminated marshes are less resistant to the S. patens increasing colonization when
exposed intermediate salt concentrations and in high salinities both H. portulacoides and S. patens have
overall better salinity tolerance than their counterparts from the non-contaminated marsh.
Concluding, this work shows that the heavy metal pre-conditioning has a complex and
considerable influence in the plants tolerance and resistance mechanisms to several abiotic stresses,
presenting an intraspecific physiological variation that can impact how the halophyte communities will
respond to the upcoming environmental changes. According to our research it can be said that the heavy
metal contaminated salt marsh will present significantly different ecological damages than their
neighboring salt marsh.
Key words: Halimione portulacoides, Spartina patens, salinity stress, warming stress, local
adaptation, intraspecific variability, salt marshes, halophytes.

General Introduction
Global warming is one of the biggest threats to the environment in the XXI century. Planet earth
is undergoing a clear shift in the climate system, with major consequences to various areas of our society,
for instance, economic, social and more importantly environmental. According to the Intergovernmental
Panel on Climatic Change Fifth Assessment Report (AR5), the influence of human activity in the global
climate change is undeniable and growing. Human population and economic growth, has been the
foremost cause of the warming observed since mid-20th century mainly due the greatly increased
emissions of anthropogenic greenhouse gases (GHGs), observed in the unprecedented increase of the of
carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide concentrations, leading to an energy uptake, translated to a
warming of the climate system (IPCC, 2014). Global warming, if mitigation efforts are not conceived,
is expected to cause further alterations to virtually all Earth environments. Under this, very likely,
scenario it is predicted a warming of the global mean surface temperature, rising of the global mean sea
level rising, as well as an increase, both in intense and frequency, of extreme climate events such as heat
waves, droughts and very large precipitation events, both in intense and frequency (Pörtner et al., 2007;
IPCC, 2014). Consequently, the climate change is very likely to alter the geographical distribution of
entire ecological systems and the variability and distribution of the species they housed.
Wetlands are known for being one of the more complex and important ecosystems worldwide,
working as an interface between the terrestrial and aquatic environments, that occur in intertidal areas,
and are providers of a wide range of essential ecosystem services (Larson et al., 1989). However,
recently published estimates show that 64% of the world's wetlands have disappeared since 1900
(Ramsar, 2013). Estuaries are coastal wetlands were the flow of fresh water from the rivers meets the
salt water of the sea. These ecosystems are characterized by wide environmental fluctuations (tidal cycle,
salinity, temperature, etc.) however, plants and animals of these ecosystems are perfectly adapted to
endure and thrive under this, normally difficult, abiotic conditions, in fact, estuaries are among the
planet's most productive ecosystems, even when compared to tropical forests (Longhurst et al., 1995).
As a result of their privileged localization, unique characteristics and natural richness the estuaries
locations have, since the beginning of civilization, attracted human populations, according to the
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA, USA), thirty-two of the largest cities in the
world are located on the coast of an estuary. Consequently, this region has suffered negative impacts
brought through the anthropogenic action such as dredging, eutrophication due to the input of organic
matter and nutrients (N and P), excessive siltation due to the intense construction activity, pollution by
solid waste, such as plastic and other debris and excessive exploitation of fishery resources, as well as
introduction of invasive species (Carter and Woodroffe, 1995). Salt marshes, characterized by their
halophyte vegetation, are established in low hydrodynamism estuarine areas and known for providing
important ecological and economical services. During tidal flooding, the sediments are trapped by the
vegetation when entering the marsh network causing marsh elevation, capturing the excesses contained
in the environment, storing pollutants and metabolizing them, for this reason they are considered the
"Kidneys of the planet" due to their important unique role in water purification (Teixeira et al., 2014).
Even though, in the past, salt marshes had been categorized as mere wastelands, nowadays their global
status as a unique ecotone recognized for their key ecological and economical importance, providing
services regarding coastal erosion and sea-level rising protection, sediment stabilization, habitat for a
diverse range of species, water purification and retention, removal and transformation of nutrients,
educational and recreational opportunities (Teixeira et al., 2014; Duarte et al., 2017). These aspects
reinforce the interest of these unique systems, in being preserved, used and fostered, either in the
currently existing marshes and in the creation of others (Catarino, 1981), since they are considered
natural methods that contribute to the removal of pollutants, leaving wastewater in better condition.
3
Halophyte vegetation, characteristic to salt marshes, is, by definition, salt-resistant or salt-
tolerant plants that can grow and complete their life cycles in soils or waters containing high salt
concentrations. These plants present physiological and morphological adaptations that make them able
to thrive in typically highly stressful environments, they are found subjected to elevated levels of abiotic
stresses, displaying considerable tolerance to heavy metal pollution, salinity, extreme thermal events
and flooding (Duarte et al., 2013a; 2013b; 2014; 2015). Despite high salt content in the vegetal tissues,
they have a high potential for utilization being a cash crop with a numerous economic and ecological
applications and purposes, such as food, fodder, coastal protection and desert revegetation (Lieth et al.,
1999; Lieth and Mochtchenko, 2002). Mediterranean salt marshes are dominated by halophyte plants
like the perennial C3-succulent Halimione portulacoides L. Aellen, and the invasive C4-grass Spartina
patens Ait. Muhl. This plants occupy different vegetation zones within the marsh, being normaly found
in the high-marsh and low-marsh respectively. The predicted climate change will have a profound
physiological impact in the salt marsh halophytes communities (Simas et al., 2001). Nevertheless,
halophyte species present different resistances and tolerances to various stresses and, if so, they will
have unalike responses to the abiotic changes fomented by global warming, moreover it is known that
intraspecific variation as a significant expression within species, especially in wide-raging and highly
tolerant species, that due to environmental pre-conditioning and acclimation to the different abiotic
conditions presented in their various habitats can show physiology, morphology, and phenology
adaptations (Valladares et al., 2007). Therefore, the direct consequences of climate change can have
different impacts on the distribution and biodiversity of the species within salt marshes, possibly due to
intraspecific variation.
This project, focused on two salt marshes found in the Tagus Estuary, Alcochete marsh and the
Rosário marsh, where the degree of heavy metal contamination (Table 1.1) is the only presumed
different abiotic condition between them. Alcochete salt marsh is located in the northern part of the
Tagus Estuary within the Tagus Estuary Natural Reserve. Rosário salt marsh is located bellow in the
estuary, near the ancient industrial axis Seixal-Montijo. Alcochete is considered a reference site with
sediment metal concentrations very low (Vinagre et al. 2008; Caçador et al. 2009), whereas Rosário salt
marsh has high levels of metal contamination in its sediments (Duarte et al. 2010).

C4-grass type halophytes

Abstract
Salt marshes are wetlands, worldwide recognized as for their unique and important ecological
role. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climatic Change, the frequency and intensity of
extreme heat events will rise because of the global warming phenomenon. Halophyte plants,
characteristic of the salt marshes and known for being highly tolerant to various abiotic stressors,
nonetheless, heat stress will have a negative impact on the individual when exposed to these warming
events, however, it has been acknowledged that the tolerance response is different from species to
species but also between same species populations. Intraspecific physiological variation is, usually,
further expressed in wide ragging species possibly due to their pre-conditioned history. The present
work aims to determine if C3-succulent Halimione portulacoides and the invasive C4-grass Spartina
patens have been conditioned to exhibit different heat tolerance within comparable same specie
populations from adjacent locations with unlike soil contamination background. Through physiology
and the photobiology analyses of warming treated samples, cross-tolerance results indicate that heavy
metal pre-conditioning significantly influence the heat stress tolerance of the tested halophyte plants.
Halimione portulacoides from a heavy metal contaminated salt marsh and S. patens from a non-
contaminated salt marsh appear to be better prepared to the upcoming consequences of the climate
change, demonstrating a higher fitness level to warming events. Thus, the pre-conditioning influence
over the tolerance mechanisms can affect the way in which salt marsh communities will evolve in the
future, possibly being different through salt marshes. The contaminated marsh can be more resilient to
invasion than the non-contaminated marsh, since the native species as benefited while the exotic was
impaired from the heavy metal pre-conditioning.
Key words: Halimione portulacoides, Spartina patens, warming stress, thermal stress, local
adaptation, intraspecific variability, Alcochete salt marsh, Rosário salt marsh.

Introduction
Wetlands systems are known to have a worldwide high economic value and ecological
importance, encompassing a large scope of ecosystem services (Larson et al., 1989; Woodward et al.,
2001). Within wetlands, salt marshes are providers of various and unique globally relevant ecological
and economic services, varying from wildlife conservation and costal defense to water purification
(Teixeira et al., 2014; Duarte et al., 2017). Usually located within marine transitional systems, normally
densely populated and industrialized areas, the marsh ecosystem is typically dominated by flora adapted
to stressful environments. Halophytes are the typical salt marsh colonizers due to their high tolerance to
varied abiotic stresses, like flooding (Duarte et al., 2014a), high salinity (Duarte et al., 2013a), heavy
metal pollution (Duarte et al., 2013b) and extreme heat and cold events (Duarte et al., 2015a), presenting
morphological and physiological adaptations that allows them to inhabit these adverse environments.
The Tagus estuary is one of these complex systems, containing various salt marshes that are affected by
various degrees of contamination, notably heavy metal contamination mostly due to local industrial
exploration and anthropogenic pollution (Caçador et al., 1996; Caçador et al., 2009; Caçador et al.,
2012). Nonetheless, the various parts of the Tagus salt march environments and most of the
Mediterranean salt marshes are abundantly colonized by the C3 succulent halophyte Halimione
portulacoides (Chenopodiaceae) and the invasive grass C4 halophyte Spartina patens (Poaceae) original
from the Atlantic Coast of North America, making then great marsh study specimens (Caçador et al.,
2013; Duarte et al., 2015b; Baumel et al., 2016a).
Nowadays in the scientist community, there is a virtual consensus that recent and historical
human activity is directly related to the observed climate change and to the unequivocal global warming.
Global warming phenomenon is predicted to have a generally negative effect on plant growth due to the
damaging effect of elevated temperatures on plant development (Hughes, 2000). Regarding the IPCC
(Intergovernmental Panel on Climatic Change) 5th Assessment Report (AR5), climate change is
described encompassing more than a century of data and analysis of the variations in temperature,
precipitation, and atmospheric composition and the several other relevant factors, represents a rather
complex and tough forecast for the local abiotic changes, impacting differently the various world
ecosystems and their related plants. This climate change is translated into a global warming that will
result in a doubtlessly 1.0 to 3.7 °C increase of the world’s average surface temperature and a surge in
heat waves events both in frequency and duration (Meehl et al., 2007). Heat wave events, as defined by
the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), is a 5º Celsius rise of the local maximum temperature
for six or more successive days, being the normal temperatures constructed defined during between
1960-1991.
Heat stress, in comparison to the other main natural occurring abiotic stresses, has an
independent effect on the plant physiology and metabolism (Bita et al., 2013). Plant tolerance to
warming stress is greatly different between species and can present relevant intraspecific variability,
furthermore, this tolerance also varies, to a certain extent, with the plant development stage (Martin et
al., 1999; Shah and Huang et al., 2011). At elevated temperatures, long-term exposure may cause
injuries or death (Schoffl et al., 1999). Plants exposed to heat stress exhibit damages in various
physiological mechanisms typically translated in the reduction of the photosynthesis activity (Duarte et
al., 2015a, 2015c, 2016b), in the decrease of “usual” protein synthesis, in membrane decay (Weis and
Berry, 1988; Larcher, 2003) among others, thus triggering physiological responses such as the
transcription and translation of heat shock proteins (HSPs; Bray et al., 2000) and production of
antioxidants and other protective molecules (Maestri et al., 2002). The temperature variation in the
environment is sensed by the plants with stets of sensors. The increased fluidity of the membrane leads
to activation of lipid-based signaling cascades and to an increased Ca2+ influx and cytoskeletal
10
reorganization (Saidi et al., 2009). Although the biological behavior and responses to warming are
similar between plants, responses to this stressor can vary throughout same species populations. This
intraspecific physiological variation can be observed in a wide range of highly tolerant species, that
possibly due to different pre-conditioning (Gratani and Crescente, 1997; Valladares et al., 2007).
Nevertheless, diverse studies indicate significant levels of interpopulation responses variability and little
intrapopulation differentiation (Jump and Penuelas, 2005).
In sum, this study intends to evaluate the effects of heavy metal-induced pre-conditioning on
warming stress responses in two, C3 and C4 widespread, halophytes from two salt marsh populations.
Using warming-induced changes in two halophytes populations with different pre-conditioning histories
(heavy metal contaminated land versus non-contaminated environment) allowed to explore the different
warming tolerances by analyzing the significant physiological variances in the response to the elevated
temperatures, which can show intraspecific variation probably due to habitat variation. Considering the
global warming projected by the IPCC report it becomes of foremost importance to identify and assess
functional traits in which environmental variability has a significant role in how the species respond to
global and local change.

Materials and methods
Study Area and Sampling
This study sampling was carried out on the Tagus estuary (Figure 2.1), located in the western
coast of Portugal (38°44?N, 9°03? W), one of the larger estuaries in occidental Europe with an area of
approximately 320 km2. The estuary involves a watershed superior to 80,000 km2 in Spain and Portugal
territories, being the second most significant hydrological basin in whole Iberian Peninsula.
Halimione portulacoides and Spartina patens sampling was done during low tide in the southern
part of the Tagus estuary on the same day and tidal period, in Alcochete salt marsh (38°45'N, 8°56'W)
situated within the Tagus Estuary Natural Reserve and Rosário salt marsh (38°40'N, 9°01'W) in the
vicinity of a large industrial complex (Figure 2.1). Samples were stored in well-identified plastic bags
and quickly brought to the Marine Botany laboratory, at the Marine and Environmental Sciences Centre
(MARE) site in the Faculty of Sciences of the University of Lisbon.
In the laboratory, plant samples were gently washed to remove dust and sediments. In order to
make steam cuttings from H. portulacoides samples, the roots and part of the stems were cut, leaving at
least two nods in the stem below the lowest branch for the development of grafts. The props were
hydroponically cultured in dark-walled vases filled with modified ¼ Hoagland nutrient solution
(Hoagland and Arnon, 1950). Spartina patens intact tussocks were set in pots filled with perlite and
irrigated with ¼ Hoagland nutrient solution. Both plant samples were placed in a fitoclimatic chamber
programmed to simulate a natural light environment using a sin function (maximum PAR 300 µmol
photons m2 s-1, 16/8 h day/night rhythm, 20/18 ºC day/night temperature amplitude). Plants were kept
under this condition for 2 months to acclimate to the new environment and allow root biomass growth
in H. portulacoides.

Pulse amplitude modulated (PAM) fluorometry
Modulated chlorophyll fluorescence measurements were made in attached leaves with a
FluoroPen FP100 PAM (Photo System Instruments, Czech Republic). All the measurements in the dark-
adapted state were made after darkening of the leaves for at least 30 min. The minimal fluorescence (F0)
in darkadapted state was measured by the measuring modulated light, which was sufficiently low (<0.1
µmol m-2 s-1) not to induce any significant variation in fluorescence. The maximal fluorescence level
(FM) in dark-adapted state was measured by a 0.8 second saturating pulse at 8000 µmol m-2 s-1. The
maximum photochemical efficiency was assessed as (FM-F0)/FM. The same parameters were also
measured in light –adapted leaves, being F’0 the minimum fluorescence, F’M the maximum fluorescence
and the operational photochemical efficiency. Rapid light curves (RLC) measurements, in dark-adapted
leaves, were attained using the preprogramed LC1 protocol of the FluoroPen, consisting in a sequence
of pulses from 0 to 500 µmol m-2 s-1. Shortly, this protocol is based in successive measurements of the
sample ?PS II under various light intensities (20, 50, 100, 200, 300 and 500 ?mol m -2 s- 1) of continuous
illumination relating the rate of photosynthesis to photon flux density (PAR). During this protocol the
F0 and FM as well as the maximum photochemical efficiency were measured. Each ?PS II measurement
was used to calculate the electron transport rate (ETR) through photosystem II using the following
equation: ETR = ?PS II x PAR x 0.5, where PAR is the actinic photosynthetically active radiation
generated by the FluoroPen and 0.5 assumes that the photons absorbed are equally partitioned between
PS II and PSI (Genty et al., 1989). Without knowledge of the actual amount of light being absorbed,
fluorescence measurements can only be used as an approximation for electron transport (Beer et al.,
1998a, Beer et al., 1998b and Runcie and Durako, 2004). Rapid light curves (RLC) were generated from
the calculated ETRs and the irradiances applied during the rapid light curve steps. Each RLC was fitted
to a double exponential decay function in order to quantify the characteristic parameters, alpha and
ETRmax (Platt et al., 1980). The initial slope of the RLC (?) is a measure of the light harvesting efficiency
13
of photosynthesis and the asymptote of the curve, the maximum rate of photosynthesis (ETRmax), is a
measure of the capacity of the photosystems to utilize the absorbed light energy (Marshall et al., 2000).
The onset of light saturation (Ek) was calculated as the ratio between ETRmax and ?. Excitation light of
650 nm (peak wavelength) from array of three light and emitting diodes is focused on the surface of the
leaf to provide a homogenous illumination. Light intensity reaching the leaf was 3000 µmol m-2 s-1,
which was sufficient to generate maximal fluorescence in all individuals. The fluorescence signal is
received by the sensor head during recording and is digitized in the control unit using a fast-digital
converter. The OJIP transient (or Kautsky curves) depicts the rate of reduction kinetics of various
components of PS II. When dark-adapted leaf is illuminated with the saturating light intensity of 3500
µmol m-2 s-1 then it exhibits a polyphasic rise in fluorescence (OJIP). Each letter reflects distinct
inflection in the induction curve. The level O represents all the open reaction centres at the onset of
illumination with no reduction of QA (fluorescence intensity lasts for 10 ms). The rise of transient from
O to J indicates the net photochemical reduction of QA (the stable primary electron acceptor of PS II) to
QA? (lasts for 2 ms). The phase from J to I was due to all reduced states of closed RCs such as QA? QB?,
QA QB 2? and QA? QB H2 (lasts for 2–30 ms). The level P (300 ms) coincides with maximum
concentration of QA? QB 2 with plastoquinol pool maximally reduced. The phase P also reflects a balance
between light incident at the PS II side and the rate of utilization of the chemical (potential) energy and
the rate of heat dissipation (Zhu et al., 2005).
Pigment profiling
Pigments analysis used the previously harvested H. portulacoides and S. patens leaf samples
that were flash-frozen and stored at -80ºC. The samples were then freeze-dried in the dark during 48h
on a Telstar laboratory freeze dryer (Cryodos-45). Subsequently, the freeze-dried leaf samples were set
into their respectively appropriately labeled plastic test tube, with the help of a glass rod, ground into a
powder and afterward it was added 5ml of pure acetone. To ensure complete disaggregation of the leaf
material, the test tubes containing the samples were then subjected to a cold ultra-sound bath for at least
2-min. The samples were immediate, stored at -20ºC freezer and the pigments were extracted for 24h,
samples were kept in in the dark to prevent pigment degradation. Following the extraction, the samples
were placed in a centrifuge set at 4000 rpm at 4ºC and centrifuged for 15min. After which, samples were
scanned from 350 nm to 750 nm in 1 nm steps, using a dual beam spectrophotometer (Shimadzu UV/VIS
UV1601 Spectrophotometer). Finally, the detected pigment sample absorption spectra were analyzed
and quantified employing Gauss-Peak Spectra (GPS) method (Kupper et al., 2007). The sample
spectrum was analyzed, through the GPS fitting library, using SigmaPlot Software. This method is based
on the sample spectrum fitting, by a linear combination, to the Gauss-peak spectra, that describes each
pigment in the detected spectrum, identifying the samples pigment profile, chlorophyll a, chlorophyll b,
autoxantihin, antheraxanthin, ?-carotene, lutein, violaxanthin, and zeaxanthin.
For a better evaluation of the light harvesting and photoprotection mechanisms, the De-
Epoxidation State (DES) was calculated as:
DES= ([Antheraxanthin]+[Zeaxanthin]) / ([Violaxanthin] + [Antheraxanthin] + [Zeaxanthin])

Leaf fatty acid composition
Leaf fatty acid analyses were performed by direct trans-esterification of the previous weighed
leaf samples as previously described (Matos et al., 2007; Duarte et al., 2017). First, leaf samples were
placed into the glass tubes, in a water bath set at 70 ºC, containing the internal standard heptadecanoate
(C17:0), methanol and sulphuric acid. Leaf samples were kept in the heated water bath, extracting for
one hour after which were cooled down. The fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) were extracted adding
diethyl ether or light petroleum and water, subsequently centrifuged at 4000 rpm during 5 min. With the
help of a glass Pasteur pipette, the upper layer was transferred to a test tube with a tapering bottom and
eventually dried with the aid of a stream of nitrogen while heated by a water bath set to 37 ºC. After the
completion of the evaporation, it was added of 50µl of hexane to the glass tube dry matter residue.
Finally, the FAMEs were separated and identified, when injected 1 µl of the solution into the gas
chromatograph (Varian 3900, Palo Alto, CA, USA) equipped with a hydrogen flame-ionization detector
using a fused silica 0.25 mm i.d. x 50 m capillary column (WCOT Fused Silica, CP-Sil 88 for FAME;
Varian).
Anti-oxidant enzyme assays
Enzyme extractions of H. portulacoides and S. patens leaf samples retrieved from their -80ºC
storage were performed according to Tiryakioglu et al. (2006), at 4ºC. The fresh leaves were
homogenized in 50mM sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.6) supplemented with 0.1 mM Na-EDTA in a
ceramic mortar with a proportion of 500 mg to 8 ml respectively. The homogenate was centrifuged at 8
923 rpm for 20 minutes at 4 °C, and the supernatant transferred to a test tube and used for the anti-
oxidant enzyme analyses.
The enzyme activity measurements of catalase (CAT, EC.1.11.1.6.), Ascorbate peroxidase
(APx, E.C. 1.11.1.11), Guaiacol peroxidase (GPX, E.C. 1.11.1.7) and Superoxide dismutase (SOD E.C.
1.15.1.1) were performed in a dual beam spectrophotometer (Shimadzu UV/VIS UV1601
Spectrophotometer) using quartz cuvettes. Catalase activity assays were performed according to the
method of Teranishi et al. (1974). An aliquot of 100 µl of extract was added to the reaction solution,
consisting in a mixture with 50 mM of sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.6), 0.1 mM of Na-EDTA, and
100 mM of H2O2, in order to start the reaction. Catalase activity was then measured by analyzing the
capacity of H2O2 consumption during 60 seconds at 25 ºC, and consequent decrease in absorbance at
240 nm (molar extinction coefficient of 39.4 mM-1 cm-1). Ascorbate peroxidase was measured according
to Tiryakioglu et al. (2006), by observing the absorbance reduction, monitored at 290 nm for 60 seconds
(molar extinction coefficient of 2.8 mM-1 cm-1). The reaction was initiated by adding 100 µl of the plant
extract to the reaction mixture consisting in 50 mM of sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.0), 12 mM of
H2O2 and 0.25 mM L-ascorbate. Guaiacol peroxidase measurement was performed according to
Bergmeyer (1974). A reaction solution was made, containing 50 mM of sodium phosphate buffer (pH
7.0), 50 mM of H2O2 and 100 µl of enzyme extract. The reaction was initiated with the addition of 20
mM of guaiacol. The activity was recorded by an increase in absorbance during 60 seconds at 470 nm
(molar extinction coefficient of 26.6 mM-1 cm-1). Superoxide dismutase total activity was assayed
according to the method of Marklund (1974), by measuring the oxidation rate of pyrogallol monitored
at 325 nm for 2 minutes. The reaction was initiated with the addition of 10 µL of enzyme extract to the
reaction mixture, consisting of 50 mM of sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.6), 0.1 mM of Na-EDTA, 3
mM of pyrogallol, ultrapure water. The autoxidation of pyrogallol was read without enzymatic extract

during the same period and time interval for comparison enabling. Protein quantification was determined
using the Bradford (1976) method.

Discussion
According to the temperature records, human influenced a worldwide environmental change
(IPCC, 2007). Since the mid-twentieth century the surge of extreme warming events is evident, and, in
some places, this recurrence has doubled (IPCC, 2014). Twenty-first-century climate model projections
concluded that the region that encompasses and surrounds the eastern Mediterranean and Middle East
is a critical area with an immense propensity for environmental changes (Tanarhte et al, 2012; Zittis et
al, 2016). Due to the future abiotic changes to the Mediterranean ecosystem, it is fair to assume
inevitable imposition of environmental stresses that will alter the biodiversity and distribution of various
ecosystems. As with any kind of new stressed environments, plants well adapted to harsh conditions,
such as salt marsh flora, will be potentially more suitable to new climate realities (Duarte et al. 2013a,
2014a, 2015). Plant populations exposed to land heterogeneity can have a different response when new
stress factors are introduced. This can happen when comparing the responses between different
conditioned species to different environments, for example, a pre-conditioned species to a more stressful
environment may have acquired functional traits that may have a determinant role in plant response to
global change, as well as on the ecological consequences at an ecosystem level for the competition
between wild and invasive species (Parmasen, 2006; Matesanz et al., 2010). Considering this,
environmental changes are impactful within ecosystems leading to potential modifications of the habitat
available for colonization. This can happen in salt marshes settings where species distribution is
frequently modulated by marsh elevation. The salt marsh zonation is based on their topography,
classified and defining several distinct areas, the low, medium and high areas, directly related to yearly
rate of tidal submergences (Adam, 1990), which is a crucial to marsh flora succession, affecting the
sediment flooding, redox potential, pH and salinity (Silvestri et al., 2005). Nevertheless, warming events
affect all the marsh flora indiscriminately. Assuming, based on the IPCC reports, that warming events
will be more frequent and long it becomes important to address the physiological mechanisms that
confer resistance and tolerance to warming stress and if this can be significantly influenced by pre-
conditioning to other stress. Comparing the physiological results of warming stress in two populations
of two widely spread halophyte species, under different environmental pre-conditions provides essential
information on plant response to new environmental factors fluctuations including climate change and
the importance of intraspecific variability.
Reviewing the photobiological light harvesting processes results, H. portulacoides populations
presented similar responses to warming treatment, reflecting well-adjusted heat tolerance processes.
There was no meaningful change in the photosystem II operational and maximum quantum yield.
Furthermore, maximum electron transport rates (ETRmax) and general photosynthetic light harvesting
efficiency (?) expanded significantly with warming treatment, bolstered by the relative electron
transport rate at each light intensity (rETR). The chlorophyll fluorescence transient analysis suggests
mechanisms that allow the maintenance of H. portulacoides photosynthetic efficiency. Nevertheless, it
can be suggested that H. portulacoides population from the heavy metal contaminated location has a
better performance when observing the slightly healthier values in the rapid light curves and derived
parameters, such as the ETRmax and photosynthetic efficiency. This inference is supported by the lower
energy dissipation values (DI/CS), indicating a higher efficiency in the electronic transport. The
relationship between the active OECs increase and the K-step amplitude decrease found in the H.
portulacoides from both locations when warming treated can be used as evidence of highly efficient
mechanisms to the imposed stress, indicating as well that the oxygen evolving complex of PS II function
was not damaged by the changed conditions (Duarte et al., 2016b), nonetheless, OECs and K-step
amplitude showed significances in their variation in the warming treated contaminated site samples,
possibly signifying a better OEC warming-stability. Still, the indication of warming stress damage is
36
reinforced by negative impacts relative to the decrease of the Kautsky curves in the warming exposed
samples. Regarding warming stress effects on photosynthetic electron transport, the decrease of
fluorescence in the Kautsky curves was the result of the decrease in quinone pool size. Quinone pool
reduction in heat stressed leaves can be acquiescent examining the limitation of the electron transport
rate, that in PS II acceptor side presented a significant reduction, considering the enactment of PS I
cyclic electron transport. A cyclic flow is known to be essential for the maintenance of the correct ratio
of ATP/NADPH production and the prevention of stroma over-reduction (Joly et al., 2007; Munekage
et al., 2004; Pshybytko et al., 2008). Thus, warming stress consequences also revealed, in both H.
portulacoides populations, a significant decrease in absorbed energy flux (ABS/CS), trapped energy
flux (TR/CS), electron transport energy flux (ET/CS) and available reaction centers (RC/CS),
nonetheless the decrease seen in the contaminated site population trapped energy flux and in their
available reaction centers was less significative indicating a better warming tolerance, presenting less
damage in overall energy fluxes. This can be supported by the visible increase in net rate of PS II reaction
of RC closure in the samples from the non-contaminated location, in contrast to the decrease found in
the heavy metal pre-conditioned samples (Chen and Cheng 2009). Furthermore, considering the
damages in warming stress of the energy fluxes in PS II and the PS I energy flux enhancement, acquired
by observing the increase displayed in ?R0 of both treated sample groups, it can be concluded that PS I
is warming resistance in comparison to the more warming unstable PS II mechanisms (Duarte et al.,
2015a). Considering that H. portulacoides is native from the Mediterranean, from North Africa to Great
Britain, is naturally adapted to warmer weather, this can explain the high physiological tolerance
displayed by this species when exposed to heat events.
PAM fluorometry acquired data, in both S. patens populations exposed to warming treatment,
presented a significant rise in PS II maximum and operational quantum efficiency in both sample
populations as well as a rise in photosynthetic efficiency and maximum electron transport rates. These
responses indicated a well-adapted response to elevated temperatures as shown in previous studies
(Duarte et al., 2016), this may be related to the fact that S. patens is a Tagus estuary invasive species
that is originally from a relatively warmer climate (Lonard et al. 2010). In fact, nowadays it is accepted
that the expansion of S. patens in Tagus estuary is slowed down by a climatic mischief of this specie to
its new invaded environment (Duarte et al., 2015b) Concerning the photosynthetic electron transport
chains in S. patens from the contaminated location, was observed a decrease in Kautsky curve
fluorescence, possibly due to the detected decrease in the oxidized quinone pool size (Pshybytko et al.,
2008). Heavy metal pre-conditioned S. patens’ oxygen evolving complexes (OECs) appear to be
temperature insensitive, on the other hand, non-contaminated site population showed a decrease in K-
step amplitude and an increase in the number of active oxygen-evolving complexes, in fact, under heat
stress K-step is exclusively related to PS II OECs (Srivastava et al., 1997), with this it can be assumed
that S. patens from the non-contaminated location have a better performance under warming exposure.
Also, results in phenomenological fluxes present significant variations between S. patens populations
response to warming stress. There was found sight variations in warming exposed non-contaminated
site samples, on the other hand, on S. patens from the contaminated location, possible due to quinone
size reduction, showed a significant reduction of electron transport energy flux (ET/CS), absorbed
energy flux (ABS/CS), trapped energy flux (TR/CS), available reaction centers (RC/CS) and energy
dissipation values (DI/CS). This significantly different response should lead to bigger consequences in
the population from the heavy metal contaminated location than those found in the analyses, however,
when considering the substantially different phenomenological fluxes values found in the control
populations, it was observed that the energy fluxes changes in contaminated site population result with
similar values in both warming exposed population. Fluorescence measurements data provided evidence
that S. patens from the non-contaminated and contaminated locations have similar performances when
exposed to warming conditions, demonstrated by the evident increase in photosynthetic similarities in
37
warming adapted S. patens. However, it can be argued that the bigger variations detected in the
phenomenological energy fluxes parameters of the heavy metal pre-conditioned S. patens reveals a
superior biological effort when responding to the warming stress compared to the population from the
non-contaminated location.
In halophytic species exposed to abiotic stresses, it is common to observe the activation of the
xanthophyll cycle (Duarte et al., 2013a, 2014a, 2014b, 2016) a photoprotective mechanism, induced due
to a crucial drop down in the luminal pH. The de-epoxidation of the luminal violaxanthin pool towards
zeaxanthin reduces the overload of the photosynthetic light harvesting mechanism, through energy
dissipation of excess reducing power accumulated within the stroma (Demmig-Adams, 1990). Heat
stressed H. portulacoides showed a decrease in all carotenoids, except non-pre-conditioned individuals
presented a significant increase in the concentration of auroxanthin, a violaxanthin analog that acts as
an efficient energy quencher, however the highly significant increase of the DES index, known to be a
evident signal of xanthophyll cycle activity, can possibly indicate a lesser presence of the xanthophyll
cycle in the plants from the non-contaminated environment (Duarte et al., 2013a). The lack of activated
carotenoids driven warming tolerance mechanisms in heavy metal pre-conditioned H. portulacoides,
did not appear to have any negative effects in the management of the LHC or in the photosynthetic
efficiency, so it can be concluded that H. portulacoides from the contaminated location has better
warming resistance. Nevertheless, both populations showed an increase in the total carotenoid to total
chlorophyll ratio, indicating a plant activity shift from light harvesting to photoprotection (Wentworth
et al., 2000). Warming exposed S. patens from the contaminated site showed xanthophyll cycle
activation and activity shift to photoprotection due to total carotenoid to total chlorophyll ratio rise,
nonetheless xanthophyll cycle is defective according to the significant increase in DES, on the other
hand, the non-contaminated site S. patens group conditions for xanthophyll cycle did not arise, however
highly significant rises in ?-carotene and lutein pigment concentrations were observed in both
populations, two typical anti-oxidant carotenoids acting as a possible countermeasure against ROS
(Duarte et al., 2013a). Moreover, pre-conditioned S. patens exhibited a highly significant increase in the
chlorophyll degradation index indicating a worse light harvesting stress response than in the non-
preconditioned individuals that presented no significant changes in the index when warming treated.
Reactive oxygen species (ROS) scavenging analysis are of great consequence because
environmental stresses can cause the accumulation of this reactive oxygen species in tissues being
harmful to plants, thus their detoxification is of major importance to plant cell metabolism. In fact, ROS
are routinely generated during normal cellular metabolic processes, yet they are also known to be
signaling molecules that can activate physiological responses to many common and frequent abiotic
stresses (Tripathy and Oelmüller, 2012). Throughout these pathways, plants have developed an effective
antioxidative mechanism, with enzymatic components coupled with mechanism driven by pigment
conversions (Jithesh et al., 2006). Nonetheless no warming treated sample groups, neither H.
portulacoides nor S. patens, shown any active line of enzymatic defense. The reduction displayed in the
anti-oxidant enzymes of the heat stressed S. patens led to a poor and inefficient scavenging mechanism
of the ROS species, observed in the highly significant increase of the lipid peroxidation, an indicator of
oxidative cellular damage. Furthermore, taking into consideration that the increase of lipid peroxidation
is higher in the pre-conditioned samples, it can be argued that the S. patens population from the non-
contaminated marsh displays less damage and superior tolerance mechanisms to ROS. On the other
hand, the defense against ROS species in H. portulacoides appears to be efficient due to the maintenance
of the lipid peroxidation levels within warming exposed plants. However, non-pre-conditioned
individuals presented the activation of the xanthophyll cycle couple with the increase production of
auroxanthin to efficiently perform ROS scavenging, none the less the pre-conditioned individuals did
not show significant anti-oxidant mechanisms, and with the reduction of auroxanthin, other common
38
ROS scavenging mechanism, it can be indicated that pre-conditioned H. portulacoides displays a better
resistance then its counterpart from the non-contaminated location.
Observing the plants fatty acid profile, we can confer that H. portulacoides and S. patens belong
to 18:3 group of plants in terms of fatty acid metabolism. Halimione portulacoides warming-exposed
populations presented similar fatty acid profile responses. Both populations shown a highly significant
increase in oleic acid (C18:1), known for improving the stabilization of light-harvesting complex
(Siefermann-Harms and Angerhofer, 1998). The findings corroborate the results that indicated light
harvesting stress, shown in the decrease of the chl a/ chl b ratio and the increase of the above mentioned
total carotenoid to total chlorophyll ratio of the heat stressed H. portulacoides. When comparing the
C18:1 to chl a/ chl b ratio there is a negative significant correlation (r2 = -0,84; P<0,05) in the individuals
from the non-contaminated marsh and (r2 = -0,89; P<0,05) in the pre-conditioned samples, this suggests
that in order to reduce LHC stress there is an increase in the synthetization of the oleic acid (Duarte et
al., 2015c). Palmitic acid (C16:0), recognized for having a key role and integral part in PS II functioning
(Gounaris and Barber, 1985) shown a highly significant increase. One of the typical heat stress
manifestations is tissue senescence, characterized by cellular membrane damage linked to a fluidity
increase of the membrane lipids, lipid peroxidation, and protein debasement in different metabolic
procedures (Savchenko et al., 2002). The substantial decrease in linolenic acid (C18:3) happen due to
the increase in the content of saturated and monounsaturated fatty acids, in order to maintain membrane
fluidity, adjusting their metabolism in direct response to the warming stress (Zhang et al.,2005). In this
manner, the expansion of the saturation level of fatty acids seems, by all accounts, to be critical for the
maintenance of the membrane stability and heat tolerance upgrading (Larkindale and Huang, 2004),
nonetheless these fatty acid tolerance mechanisms when seen more efficient in the pre-conditioned
individuals and coupled with the highly significant increase in the total fatty acid content, it can be
argued that the H. portulacoides from the heavy metal contaminated salt marsh has a superior tolerance
to heat stress. Warming feedbacks were similar between S. patens population, as well as no evident
warming specific fatty acid indicator was shown, possibly indicating no membrane structural damage.
Palmitic acid (C16:0) and oleic acid (C18:1) suffered a significant rise, probably for the benefit of
overall PS II function and more specific PS II light-harvesting complexes stabilization (Siefermann-
Harms and Angerhofer, 1998) respectively. Considering the warming stress in both populations, the
LHC stress response were different between populations. Oleic acid when compared with chl a/b ratio,
a common stress indicator, exhibited a negative correlation in the samples from the non-contaminated
(r2 = -0,75; P<0,05) and contaminated (r2 = -0,83; P<0,05) locations, although non-pre-conditioned
individuals also displayed an increase in carotenoid to chlorophyll ratio, indicating an enhancing the
light harvesting efficiency and reducing the stress, to corroborated this findings it was found a positive
correlation between C18:1 and chl a/b ratio in the individuals from the non-contaminated (r2 = 0,928;
P<0,05), in turn pre-conditioned samples as expected did not presented a correlation (r2 = 0,83; P<0,05),
the difference in LHC stress response is seen observing the chl a/b ratio decrease, that is significant and
very significant in the S. patens from the non-contaminated and the heavy metal contaminated salt marsh
respectively. Thru this data it can be claim that the non-pre-conditioned S. patens population as a
superior warming stress response than its counterpart.
39
Conclusions
The findings here obtained, support the understanding that halophyte plants are known to be
tolerant to a wide range of abiotic stresses, possessing highly efficient mechanisms that allow them to
colonize inherently hostile habitats just like the sampled salt marshes. This study has shown that thermal
stress in both, the C3 Halimione portulacoides and the C4 Spartina patens, halophytes species presented
a complex intraspecific variation of their biophysical stress responses imposed through environmental
warming, related to local adaptation to other stress due to different habitat conditions presented in the
populations.
Our data suggest that although H. portulacoides from both populations showed overall negative
impacts to warming events. Nonetheless, heavy metal pre-conditioned H. portulacoides displayed less
damage in the physiological and the photobiological mechanisms than its non-contaminated site
counterpart, revealing to have better warming tolerance. Photobiological light harvesting processes
appear to have a higher efficiency in the H. portulacoides from the heavy metal contaminated location,
presenting less damage to the photosystem II electronic transport and energy flux. Considering
photoprotective mechanisms, the xanthophyll cycle seems to be only needed in the non-contaminated
site H. portulacoides, when observing no more damage or photoinhibition in H. portulacoides from the
contaminated location it appears that non-contaminated site H. portulacoides are possibly more
photosensitive. Spartina patens results suggests a high tolerance for temperature increase stress in both
populations. Nonetheless, an argument can be made indicating a better and more efficient warming
adaptation in S. patens sourced from the non- contaminated environment. Regarding photobiology, it
can be detected an improvement in the PS II oxygen-evolving complexes in the non-contaminated site
S. patens as well as being, apparently, warming insensitive, the same thus not applied in S. patens from
the heavy metal contaminated location, presenting various significant photobiological mechanisms
changes. The heavy metal pre-conditioned S. patens, when comparing to S. patens from the non-
contaminated environment, also appear to show the poorest warming tolerance with an apparent photo-
oxidative stress vulnerability as well as a less competent reactive oxygen species scavenging
mechanisms.
Assuming that the IPCC predictions are accurate, the heat wave phenomenon will be
substantially aggravated, in frequency and duration, by the ongoing climate change that is expected to
have a great impact in plant distribution and abundance in the world’s salt marsh ecosystem, as well as
plant community distribution (Walther et al., 2002). Different responses to extreme climate events can
occur between plant species especially those that have a wide-ranging geographical distribution (Jump
and Penuelas, 2005) just as the plant species addressed in this study. Our findings suggest that H.
portulacoides from a heavy metal contaminated salt marsh and S. patens from a non-contaminated salt
marsh to there are better suited for the upcoming environmental reality, being more warming tolerant
than their counterparts. Therefore, in the heavy metal contaminated marsh in comparison to the non-
contaminated marsh, climate change appears to affect negatively the C4 invasive S. patens heat tolerance
while increasing the performance of the C3 native H. portulacoides to warming events, which can
dissuade the invasion trend showed by the S. patens, hence cross-tolerance favors the native species in
the heavy metal contaminated environment. The same cannot be said in non-contaminated marsh,
whereas climate change will promote the invasion of the exotic species.
Thus, environmental pre-conditioning observed in this species can be considered to have an
important influencing factor in how the plant tolerance mechanisms respond to abiotic changes, varying
significantly in accordance with their environmental histories.

C4-grass type halophytes

Abstract
Land salinization is an increasing problem everywhere due to the excessive irrigation practices
in agricultural production needed to supply the also increasing world population, however this
phenomenon is predicted to be even higher in coastal regions. Water and soil salinity is predicted to
increase thru the rising storm and tidal surges and sea level rising, currently millions of people live in
low elevation costal-lands with risk of salinization. Nearly all plants are significantly damage or die
when exposed to high salt concentration, on the other hand halophyte plants, typically encountered in
salt marshes, are able to live and thrive in soil salinities up to 855mM. Nevertheless, halophyte species
experience between then a difference in their salt tolerance range and optimal salinity, this is a
determined factor in the plant distribution through the marsh. Additionally, intraspecific variation to
NaCl response is commonly observed in high raging halophyte species, possibly due to population
conditioned by local abiotic factors that can influence the overall plant physiology, therefore the pre-
conditioning influence becomes meaningful to understand the evolution of salt marsh ecology through
the expected consequences of climate change. In order to comprehend this implication this study aimed
to understand if a different environmental condition will change the way salt marsh species react when
exposed to a range of high salinities, analyzing the effects that salt stress as on the physiology and the
photobiology. The results show that heavy metal pre-conditioning has a significant and complex role in
changing the salt tolerance mechanism of C3-succulent Halimione portulacoides and the invasive C4-
grass Spartina patens. Therefore, the pre-condition history of halophyte populations appears to have
greatly influence their future distribution outcome. Whereas at a soil salinity of 400mM, the non-pre-
conditioned invasive individuals can display a disadvantage in the salt tolerance when compared to those
belonging to the population from the heavy metal contaminated location and at 800mM NaCl both heavy
metal pre-conditioned H. portulacoides and S. patens appear to have a higher fitness when compared to
the species their counterparts from the non-contaminated marsh. Thus, the contaminated salt marsh can
be not only more less resilient to the S. patens colonization, but their halophyte species can be overall
more salt tolerant due to their heavy metal pre-conditioning.
Key words: Halimione portulacoides, Spartina patens, salinity stress, salt tolerance, local
adaptation, intraspecific variability, Alcochete salt marsh, Rosário salt marsh.

Introduction
According to the latest IPCC report, the analysis of the data gathered, through this and the last
century, a worldwide intensification of abiotic stresses, such as the increase and intensity of extreme
climate events, droughts, floods, sea level rising, water and land salinity variations are extremely likely
with alarming environmental and economic implications (IPCC, 2014). Earth can be considered a salt
planet since approximately, 97.5% of all planet’s water content is salt water, occupying roughly 70% of
the surface encompassed in oceans, lake and groundwater (Shiklomanov, 2009), additionally, it has been
estimated that high soil salinity is affecting 20% of total Earth’s land surface and 33% of agricultural
irrigated lands (Glick et al., 2007, Shrivastava et al., 2014). Therefore, it can be presumed that soil and
water salinity induced stress is and will be one of the major abiotic stresses. Usually, salt stress in plants
is a powerful limiting production factor, upsetting every major crop development and productivity
(Bacilio et al., 2004). Furthermore, most crops plants, generally, cannot grow in soils with NaCl
concentrations higher than 40mM NaCl (Munns, 2005; Jamil et al., 2011). The constant increase in the
world population results in higher food demand that leads to a more excessive irrigation practices to
match the need for agricultural production hence contributing to the progressive land salinization. In
coastal regions, especially in the high populated estuaries, climate change will likely increase, at an
elevated rate, the soil and water salinity, mostly due to predicted storm surges, tidal surges and sea level
rise causing an onward saltwater land inundation (Dasgupta and Hossain et al., 2015). Nowadays more
than 600 million people live in considerable salinization risk areas, inhabiting low-elevation coastal
lands (Wheeler, 2011). This presents a severe threat not only to coastal ecosystems but also to the
agriculture, aquaculture and freshwater availability jeopardizing the sustainability of the growing human
population (Flowers, 2004). Most of the crop plants when exposed to NaCl concentrations from 40 mM
to 200 mM become severely damage or die, plants exposed to elevated salt concentrations result in
several complex biochemical, physiological, and morphological damages, such as nutrient uptake and
assimilation. (Munns and Tester, 2008; Akbarimoghaddam et al., 2011). On the other hand, and contrary
to 99% of all the plant species, halophytic vegetation species can not only survive but be highly
productive in saline environments. Halophytes are, by definition, plants that can live normally and
complete their life cycle under a salt concentration of at least 200 mM, with most plants experiencing
tolerance to a remarkable amplitude of NaCl concentration (Flowers and Colmer, 2008). However, it is
known that different halophytes species have unlike responses to same salinity, ranging from species
having optimal performance in salt-free environments to high NaCl concentration such as 400 mM
(Flowers and Colmer, 2008; Duarte et al., 2014c). Intraspecies salt tolerance variations are relevant
when taking into consideration the potential salinity environment modification due to climate change,
that will most likely change salt tolerant plant habitat availability and distribution, within an ecosystem.
This is evident in most halophytes populated salt marshes, where species distribution is organized and
clearly observed within marsh topography and morphology, where plants are arranged according to soil
elevation. Salinity tolerance is certainly related to plant zonation, salinity increases with soil elevation
when, due to extended evaporation periods in higher elevation, however above mean high sea level
(MHSL) salt concentration drops again, this time due to relative rare flooding (Adam, 2002; Caçador et
al., 2007). Nonetheless, many studies suggest that intraspecific salt tolerance variations can occur in
different populations (Hester et al., 1996; Flowers 2004). When intraspecific NaCl response is taken
into consideration it may show a different response to same NaCl concentration, therefore it is important
to understand coastal ecosystem modification and evolution once exposed to salinity changes.
Tagus estuary wetland is considered one of the more important in Europe and encompasses the
most extensive and continuous salt marsh area in Portugal, presenting a great concentration of organic
matter and biological productivity. Salt marshes located within this estuary share most of the colonized
47
halophyte species, such as the C3 halophyte Halimione portulacoides (Chenopodiaceae) and the C4
halophyte Spartina patens (Poaceae) and exhibit mostly similar abiotic conditions but, due to
anthropogenic actions, there is also presence of significant difference in soil contaminants, notably
industrial caused heavy metals pollution (Caçador et al., 1996). On account of climate change, it is
predicted a variation of salinity concentrations and distribution in the estuary and a saltwater movement
upstream due to sea level rising (Rodrigues et al., 2016). Salinity alterations in the environment will
have a heavy impact all the Tagus estuary wetlands ecosystems certainly upsetting the development and
distribution of the plant populations.
The aim of this study was to investigate the influence of heavy metal pre-conditioning in the
physiological responses of two halophyte species to different saline environments. By means of
imposing salinity treatments on two different heavy metal pre-conditioned populations of two widely
spread halophyte species, it was possible to evaluate significant intraspecific variability in the
physiological salt tolerance mechanisms. In view of the on-going climate change, it is relevant the
knowledge of the differently conditioned salt marshes species potential to adapt and respond, directly
related to future salt-induced habitat modifications, with respect to plant distribution and frequency.

Materials and methods
Study Area and Sampling
This study sampling was carried out as described in Chapter 2, section 2.1, and the samples used for
salinity treatment were from the same group of samples gathered and grown for warming treatments
explain in the second Chapter.
Experimental setup
In the lab, H. portulacoides and S. patens samples collected in Alcochete and Rosário salt marshes,
after four-month adaptation and growth period, were separated into 3 groups with 5 replicates each
(Table 3.1) and subjected to different salt concentration. The sample groups were placed in a fitoclimatic
chamber programmed to simulate a natural light environment using a sin function (maximum PAR 300
µmol photons m2 s-1, 16/8 h day/night rhythm, 20/18 ºC day/night temperature amplitude) and the
hoagland nutrient solution was replaced, in two sample groups, with two salinity treatment solution of
¼ Hoagland solution supplemented with NaCl in order to attain the desired salinities (400 and 800 mM).
To detect salinity stress signs, the salinity treatment had a duration of 7 days after which the plants were
harvested. All leave samples for biochemical measurements were immediately flash-frozen in liquid-N2
and stored at -80ºC until analysis. Leaf samples harvested for fatty acid analysis were weighed before
frozen.
