Discussion
Effects of environmental change on coastal regions include the progressive land immersion from
ocean level rise, heightened storm damage, expanding drought seasons and temperature increase. This
environmental abiotic alteration has consequences in the salinity gradient, with recent studies
forecasting disturbing impacts of salinity disturbance in waterfront areas (Wheeler, 2011; Dasgupta et
al., 2015). Thus, halophyte plant colonization will be of foremost importance to future environmental
change.
Photochemical analysis of the Halimione portulacoides and Spartina patens samples exposed
to salt treatments confirmed that these species have a high degree of tolerance to salinity even at high
NaCl concentrations. Nevertheless, it was shown an apparent variation of the consequences and
responses to different NaCl concentrations between individuals from different populations. Examining
the PS II light harvesting mechanism in H. portulacoides and S. patens it is evident the that both
halophyte species are well adapted to salt environments. Halimione portulacoides at 400 mM NaCl
showed an increase in the photosynthetic efficiency (?) when compared to the individuals at 0 mM
NaCl. This data is in accordance with other studies (e.g. Duarte et al., 2014) that reveal the better
performance of H. portulacoides at approximately these salt concentrations. However, the
photosynthetic efficiency presented a significant increase in the individuals from the non-contaminated
marsh and coupled with the significant raise of the maximum ETR seen in the same sample group
suggests a better overall light harvesting efficiency to 400 mM NaCl enrich environments than the
individuals from the heavy metal contaminated marsh. Additionally, the comparatively low value of
photosynthetic efficiency found in the 0 mM NaCl treated pre-conditioned samples may suggest that
non-contaminated site H. portulacoides have better fitness under brackish conditions as well. Even
though it can be considered that H. portulacoides is an obligatory halophyte, negative impacts, due to
salinity stress, were found in the decrease of the active OECs and the increase of the K-step amplitude
in the 400 mM salt treatment samples, the relationship of this parameters indicates a specific damage to
the oxygen evolving complex of PS II donor side (Duarte et al., 2016b). Considering the Kautsky curves,
salinity stress harmful consequences are also shown by the fluorescence decrease tendency throughout
the increasing salt concentration treatments, directly related to the decrease tendency detected in the
oxidized quinone pool size, when related with the PS II acceptor side (Strasser et al., 1995).
Additionally, it was observed variations between the curves displayed by the different H. portulacoides
population samples within same salt treatment, O-J step of the non-contaminated site samples indicate
a greater damage to the photochemical energy production in the chloroplasts from both salinity
treatments, on the other hand pre-conditioned individuals at 400 mM NaCl showed a lesser efficiency
in the dissipation of the excessive energy throughout thermal dissipation than its counterpart, as shown
in the J-I-P step, this can have photo-inhibition consequences in the individuals from the heavy metal
contaminated marsh due to the fact that this characterizes an important ROS reducing mechanism
(Duarte et al. 2014c). This assessment is confirmed in the analyzed phenomological energetic parameter,
where a decrease tendency of the trapped energy flux (TR/CS), the electron transport energy flux
(ET/CS) and the number of available reaction centers for reduction (RC/CS) was present throughout the
salinities treatments with more intensity and with bigger significance in non-contaminated site samples.
Although the quinone poll available for reduction was diminished, the RC turnover rate increase
especially in pre-conditioned H. portulacoides individuals exposed to higher salinities, indicating lower
quinone reduction rates (Duarte et al., 2016b). Pre-conditioned individuals presented an increase in net
rate of PS II reactive centres as a counteractive measure, allowing higher energy fluxes than the non-
pre-conditioned individuals as previously seen (Panda et al., 2006; Kalaji et al., 2011). The PS I ?R0
presented a significantly improved activity through the salt stressed individuals from the contaminated
72
marsh, indicating a tolerance mechanism to prevent accumulation of reduction power at the PS I acceptor
side, in order to maintain the redox equilibrium between photosystems (Krüger et al., 2014; Duarte et
al., 2016b), on the other hand this mechanism has not present in the non-pre-conditioned samples.
Nevertheless, when compared to the individuals from the non-contaminated marsh the pre-conditioned
H. portulacoides displayed greater signs of PS II antennae connectivity disruption, as shown by PG,
especially when exposed to 800 mM NaCl, impairing the energetic transport (Strasser and Strirbet,
2001). The loss of connectivity between PS II antennae can be a major reason for the comparatively
lower photosynthetic efficiency and J-I-P step observed in the pre-conditioned individuals at 400 mM
NaCl, as a result of the inhibition of the ETC (Zushi et al., 2012). According to the PAM fluorometry
data, it can be argued that the H. portulacoides from the non-contaminated location had a better
performance when exposed to 400 mM NaCl conditions, on the other hand, at 800 mM NaCl, the heavy
metal pre-contained individuals presented a slightly better biophysical feedback.
Considering the electron transport chain and related parameters in salt treated S. patens, when
compared to 0 mM NaCl, it was observed a significant raise in overall photosynthetic light efficiency in
pre-conditioned individuals at 400mM NaCl as well as significant decrease in maximum ETR at 400mM
and 800mM NaCl in non-contaminated and contaminated site samples respectively. This may suggest a
worse electron transport chain proficiency in S. patens from the heavy metal contaminated location when
expose to 800mM NaCl concentrations, in contrast to a better performance in S. patens from the non-
contaminated site when exposed to that same high salinity. The pre-contaminated individuals that
showed an increase in the photosynthetic efficiency at 400 mM NaCl also displayed a relatively low
dissipation energy, suggesting a higher efficiency in the electronic transport chain. Observing the
Kautsky curves in S. patens, exposure to salinity clearly affected the fluorescence values, presenting, in
individuals subjected to high salinities, a depressed and homogenous profile with less distinguishable
peaks, characteristic of stressed plants. Nevertheless, the active OECs and the K-step amplitude
remained the same, with no significant changes, within marsh sample groups, yet the relationship
between this Kautsky curve derived parameters, when comparing the non-pre-conditioned and pre-
conditioned salinity treated samples, can indicate a better PS II function in the heavy metal pre-
conditioned S. patens. The loss of the area above the transient curve is directly associated to the size of
the oxidized quinone pool (Strasser et al., 1995), that in turn will greatly influence the phenomological
energetic parameters (Kalaji et al., 2011). According to the data acquired, in the salt exposed samples
groups, there is a linear relationship between the variation found in the oxidized quinone pool size the
electron transport energy flux, the absorbed energy flux (ABS/CS), the trapped energy flux, as well as
the available reaction centers, nonetheless, the population showed differences in significance among
these values. Even though the pre-conditioned S. patens at 400 and 800 mM NaCl, when compared to
the samples at 0 mM NaCl, showed a more significant decrease in quinone pool size, yet the reduction
in the electron transport energy flux was less significant than the one displayed in the individuals from
the non-contaminated site, this can be explain by the better PS II efficiency associated with the lower
dissipation energy flux found in the pre-conditioned individuals (Kalaji et al., 2011). Although the
quinone pool size, in the individuals from the non-contaminated location subjected to salinity stress,
displayed no significant changes in the number of quinones, the number of quinone turnovers increased,
showing lower quinone pool reduction rates (Duarte et al., 2016b), in contrast the individuals from the
contaminated marsh exhibited a significant reduction of the quinone pool size and no significant changes
in its turnover time, indicating tolerance mechanisms that allowed the maintenance of electronic flow
rate from the reduced quinone pool to the electron transport chain ( Duarte et al., 2014c).
Xanthophyll cycle is a well-described mechanism of energy dissipation, commonly observed in
halophytic plants (Duarte et al, 2013a, 2014a, 2014b, 2016b). To reduce energy overload within light-
harvesting complexes (LHCs), the de-epoxidation of the violaxanthin pool towards the zeaxanthin is
normally activated (Wentworth et al., 2000). Both H. portulacoides populations shown the presence of
73
xanthophyll cycle, demonstrated by the highly significant raises in de-epoxidation when salt treated in
comparison to the samples at 0 mM NaCl. Halimione portulacoides also showed increase tendency in
the total carotenoid to total chlorophyll ratio, indicating a plant activity shift from light harvesting to
photoprotection (Wentworth et al., 2000). Both high salinity treated samples from both location shown
a significant increase in auroxanthin, an analog of violaxanthin, a C5,8 carotenoid with an aggregation
-associated querying capacity (Ruban et al., 1998), when compared to the 0 mM NaCl treated groups.
This pigment energy dissipation capacity relies on the fact that the auroxanthin first energy stage is
higher than that of the violaxanthin (Wentworth et al., 2000), an efficient energy quencher when the
plant is stressed (Ruban et al., 1998). Nonetheless, H. portulacoides from the non-contaminated site
presents a higher significance in the increase of this pigment at 400 mM NaCl then its counterpart,
suggesting a better energy dissipation mechanism in the non-pre-conditioned samples at 400 mM NaCl,
corroborating the inferences made when observing their Kautsky curves, that suggested that heavy metal
pre-conditioned samples displayed a lesser energy dissipation efficiency. Moreover, chlorophyll
degradation index increased highly significantly within the high concentration salt treatments except in
the non-pre-condition individual at 400 mM NaCl, pointing to a better light harvesting stress response.
Considering S. patens exposed to salinity, only in 800 mM NaCl treatments in both population samples,
showed a highly significant increase in de-epoxidation, reflection of a higher activity of the xanthophyll
cycle attempting to scatter the excessive redox potential amassed inside the stroma. The activity shift to
photoprotection in the higher salinities was also clear due to the significant rise of total carotenoid to
total chlorophyll ratio. As a possible countermeasure against reactive oxygen species (ROS; Duarte et
al., 2013a) highly significant rises were observed in ?-carotene and lutein, anti-oxidant acting, pigment
concentrations in both H. portulacoides salt exposed populations. In S. patens, this countermeasure was
found more significant in the population from the non-contaminated marsh, as a highly significant
increase in ?-carotene was found in the contaminated site samples at 800mM NaCl and at both high
salinity concentration in the plants from the non-contaminated location, as well as a highly significant
increase in lutein at 800 mM NaCl. This may indicate a better ROS savaging response by pre-
conditioned S. patens.
The interaction of high NaCl concentrations with the cell organelles leads to an increase
production ROS resulting in potentially harmful physiological reactions within the plant cells, affecting
among others, proteins production and metabolism (Duarte et al., 2013b). Halophytes built up a highly
proficient system of enzymatic rapid responses toward salinity changes, immediately activated when the
environmental conditions shift aside from the saline comfort zone (Zhou et al., 2014). When observing
the salt treated H. portulacoides populations, it showed similar responses in the second line of ROS
defense between them, displaying comparable value changes in the peroxidase-class enzymes, such as,
catalase (CAT), guaiacol peroxidase (GPx), and ascorbate peroxidase, that are fundamental for the
detoxification of the hydrogen peroxide and key in the reduction of ROS to non-damaging
concentrations (Duarte et al., 2014c). However, at the first line of defense, superoxide dismutase (SOD),
which catalyzes the conversion of the highly toxic superoxide anions to hydrogen peroxide (Duarte et
al., 2014c), exhibited a highly significant increase in in the 800 mM NaCl treated individuals from the
non-contaminated marsh. This coupled with the highly significant decrease of the total protein content
found in this same group, subjects that, when exposed to 800 mM NaCl, the non-preconditioned H.
portulacoides had a higher ROS production than the pre-conditioned H. portulacoides, indicating lower
resistance to high Na+ interaction. Scavenging mechanisms of ROS species were highly efficient at 400
mM NaCl due to the lowering of the lipid peroxidation levels in comparison to the individuals at 0 mM
NaCl, this was acquired from the analysis of the leaf malondialdehyde (MDA) concentration, a direct
product oxidative degradation of membrane lipids (Neto et al., 2005), this indicates and is in accordance
with the knowledge that H. portulacoides is better adapted to a 400mM NaCl setting than no salt
environment. However, the MDA decrease present in both 400mM NaCl treatments was more
74
significant in the non-contaminated site individuals and consequently can be considered healthier and
more salt tolerant in comparison to their H. portulacoides counterpart, possibly due to the better energy
dissipation mechanism seen previously in the plants from the non-contaminated marsh. When
comparing the oxidative stress biomarkers in S. patens, variances between populations are clear.
Contrary to what was found in the pre-conditioned S. patens, the non-contaminated site individuals
displayed an increase of superoxide dismutase and a decrease in total protein content through NaCl
treatments, suggesting an inferior scavenging mechanism of the ROS species. This is especially felt in
the non-pre-conditioned S. patens at 800 mM NaCl due to higher lipid peroxidation levels, seen thru the
highly significant increase of the MDA concentration.
The fatty acid profiles of the salt exposed halophytes presented similar responses amongst
populations, but some differences were found. The linoleic (C18:2) and linolenic (C18:3) ratios can be
a salt stress indication, when under stress condition the ratio shifts towards linolenic, since it is a
membrane restructuring with lower amounts of polyunsaturated acids, thus inferior C18:3 concentration
in the leaf is considered an adaptation to salt exposure (Hamed et al. 2005). The C18:2/ C18:3 ratio
increased exclusively through the NaCl treatments in the heavy metal pre-conditioned S. patens,
therefore tis can suggest that these individuals are less salinity stressed than those from the non-
contaminated location. Furthermore, C18:3 can also act as a direct non-enzymatic reactive oxygen
species (ROS) scavenger (Mene-Saffrane et al. 2009), which complies with the, comparatively, lower
ROS consequences found previously in the pre-conditioned S. patens. Furthermore, pre-conditioned S.
patens displayed highly significant rise in oleic acid (C18:1), known for improving the stabilization of
light-harvesting complexes (Siefermann-Harms and Angerhofer, 1998), as seen by the positive
significant correlation between LHC stress indictor chl a/ chl b ration and the C18:1 fatty acid significant
correlation (r2 = 0,921; P<0,05), on the other hand in the individuals from the non-contaminated site the
correlation between this two variables is quite low (r2 = 0,161; P<0,05), indicating that this mechanism
only occur in the plants from the heavy metal contaminated marsh. Regarding the palmitic acid (C16:0),
that plays a vital role in the PS II functioning (Duarte et al., 2016b), in H. portulacoides the highly
significant increases, when compared to individuals at 0 mM NaCl, where found in the non-pre-
conditioned individuals at 400 mM NaCl and in pre-conditioned individuals at 800 mM NaCl, indicating
a better PS II functioning in these sample groups than their counterparts, supporting the inferences made
when analyzing the H. portulacoides PAM fluorometry data. Tras-delta-3 hexadecenoic acid (C16:1t),
exclusive to plastids (Trémolières and Siegenthaler, 1983) and the only strictly light dependent fatty
acid, enables the correct organization of light-harvesting antennae complexes (Nussberger et al., 1993;
Hobe et al., 1994; ‚ Hobe et al., 1995; Duarte et al., 2016). In S. patens, when compared to the
individuals at 0 mM NaCl, a significant increasing trend was found in the C16:1t concentration of the
individuals from the contaminated marsh, concomitant with the, previously determined, lower energy
dissipation and reduced reaction centres turnover and closure rates found in the pre-conditioned samples,
comparatively to those found in the individuals from the non-contaminated marsh, proposing a better
LHC organization and heath in the heavy metal pre-conditioned S. patens when exposed to salt stress.
75
Conclusions
The invasion of exotic species to new environments are regulated by numerous abiotic
restrictions (Daehler and Strong, 1996), the same is applied to the distribution and survival of the native
species when the forecasted climate change phenomenon alters the ecosystem abiotic settings. Salt
marshes ecosystems are characterized for being high salinity ecosystems, where only halophytes, salt
tolerant plants are able to endure, on the other hand, species have different salinity tolerances,
consequently salinity concentration is one of the major constraints of species frequency, distribution and
zonation (Silvestri et al., 2004; Duarte et al., 2014c).
This study showed that both C3 Halimione portulacoides and the invasive C4 Spartina patens
are extremely tolerant to high concentration salinity changes, even being able to adapt to an environment
roughly twice as saline as the ocean. Nonetheless, our findings showed that environmental heavy metal
pre-conditioning have a considerable influence on the salinity tolerance mechanisms and salinity
resistance of these plants. The halophyte species displayed noteworthy intraspecific biophysical and
biochemical variations when exposed to salty stress, due to the significantly different pre-conditioning
history between populations. According to the data gathered and in agreement to previous studies, H.
portulacoides exposed to 400 mM NaCl appear to have a better photosynthetic efficiency, however,
even though H. portulacoides from the contaminated marsh displayed better photochemical energy
production, as seen in the O-J step and the energy fluxes, the non-pre-conditioned plants at 400 mM
NaCl displayed an overall better performance at this salinity mostly due to a better ability to dissipate
energy seen in the J-I-P step, this is supported by the reduced ROS damage and the better energy
dissipation mechanism, apparent in the more significant auroxanthin increase that suggests a more
efficient energy dissipation mechanism. On the other hand, 800 mM NaCl treated H. portulacoides from
the non-contaminated location exhibited an overall inferior response to this high salinity concentration.
Heavy metal pre-conditioned H. portulacoides at 800 mM NaCl showed an seemingly more efficient
salt tolerance, demonstrated in the lesser damages in photochemical energy production, showing a
comparatively better photon entrapment and energy transferred in the transport chain, clearly seen in the
variances between the phenomological energetic parameters of both populations as well as increasing
in palmitic acid that acted as a countermeasure to the salinity stress, ensuring the PS II functioning.
Regarding the variances found in the stress responses in the salinity exposed S. patens populations, it
was apparent that the heavy metal contaminated marsh population exhibited lesser damages due to
comparatively more efficient salt tolerance mechanisms. Pre-conditioned individuals appear to have
significantly more effective biochemical responses that the individuals from the non-contaminated site,
that appear to withstand harshest photochemical consequences as seen by the decrease throughout higher
salt concentrations of the chlorophyll a/b ratio, contrarily to the increase tendency found in the pre-
conditioned. This correlating with the highly significant increase in oleic acid found only in pre-
conditioned S. patens, indicates that the plants from this population have an effective light-harvesting
complexes stabilization mechanism, on the other hand, non-pre-conditioned appear to display
impairments in the LHC mechanisms, that coupled with the comparatively deficient energy dissipation
mechanisms, seems to lead to higher ROS generation and as consequence greater plant damage.
Rendering the latest IPCC report, the variation in salinity concentration will intensify and will
have highly detrimental consequences on the world’s coastal ecosystems. In Tagus estuary is predicted
a meaningful change in the salinity concentrations and distribution upstream due to sea level rising
(Rodrigues et al., 2016). As environmental salinity is one of the major constraints to the distribution and
colonization of plant species along salt marsh (Duarte et al, 2014c), climate change will directly affect
the valuable salt marsh ecosystem and their communities. However, complexes and significant
interspecific variations in the biophysical and biochemical responses to salt stress were observed in the
76
studied halophytes, due to their different pre-conditioned histories. This will potentially shape the future
salt marsh communities. Our findings suggest heavy metal pre-conditioning do not have a linear
influence throughout higher salt concentrations. Halimione portulacoides had a relatively worse
performance when heavy metal pre-conditioned at 400 mM NaCl, on the other hand at 800 mM NaCl
had a better performance, moreover S. patens displayed a better performance when heavy metal pre-
conditioned in both high salinities. Therefore, when the environmental salinity reaches 400 mM the
heavy metal contaminated marsh may experience a more aggressive S. patens invasion and spreading
than in the non-contaminated marsh, possibly signifying more negative ecological impacts in the
contaminated salt marsh biodiversity. Nonetheless, at very high salinities such as 800 mM, both H.
portulacoides and S. patens from the heavy metal salt marsh appear to have a higher fitness and salt
tolerance than those form the non-contaminated marsh, meaning that it may be more resistant to nearly
deathly salt concentrations, potentially able to survive salinities that the other marsh community could
not.
Thus, heavy metal pre-conditioning could potentially be a key factor to understand the species
adaptation to the climate change reality, subsequently, halophyte species intraspecific salt tolerance
variances due to abiotic pre-conditioning are essential when considering climate change scenarios.

Chapter IV Final considerations
81
Final considerations
Wetlands are recognized as one of the most complex and important ecosystems in our world,
displaying a fundamental ecological and economic role enveloping a vast array of essential services
(Larson et al., 1989; Woodward et al., 2001). However, despite humanity intrinsically rely on the
benefits provided by wetlands, according to the 2017 Ramsar Policy Brief 1, more than half of the
world’s wetlands have been lost in the past one hundred years due to anthropogenic actions.
Furthermore, this loss and ecosystem degradation continues at an alarming rate around the world,
contributing to lower resilience to disasters and climate change. Salt marshes are coastal wetlands,
located in low hydrodynamism estuarine areas. These ecosystems have evolved to endure harsh
environmental conditions and fluctuations and, as stated before, are provides of a wide range of unique
services such as coastal protection, water purification and retention, nutrient transformation, sediment
stabilization, shelter for migratory birds, fish and shellfish nurseries, among others (Teixeira et al., 2014;
Duarte et al., 2017). Salt marshes, due to the many abiotic and anthropogenic pressures and stressors
that they are typically subjected, are characteristically colonized by the very resilient halophyte
vegetation. Although halophytes plants can survive and even thrive in exceptionally stressful
environments (Duarte et al., 2013a; 2013b; 2014; 2015), human impacts coupled with climate change
will have profound consequences in coastal salt marshes (Simas et al., 2001; Lotze et al., 2006). Hence,
the preservation of these unique ecotone is vital, and it has become a conservation priority in most
counties. In order to predict the ongoing climate change impacts in the marsh ecosystem and its
community a systematic understanding of physiological mechanisms underlying marsh vegetation
resistance mechanisms might not be enough, considering that intraspecific variation as a significant
expression within wide-raging and highly tolerant species, due to specific environmental pre-
conditioning exposure. Thereby commonly occurring halophyte species may maintain, within different
populations, a variety of physiology, morphology, and phenology local specializations that will be have
an influence in their feedback to future environmental stresses (Valladares et al., 2007). Moreover,
nowadays, the potential to significant intraspecific variation between neighbor populations is more
evident than ever, on account of human impact on a specific location and ecosystem, as shown
previously in the heavy metal contamination of the Rosário salt marsh due to industrial activities (Duarte
et al., 2013b). In the face of climate change, these issues are of utmost importance and in order to
understand and protect this ecosystem, reinforcing the need to study the causal-effect relationship and
variabilities between environmental changes and ecosystem changes.
This study covered two wide-ranging halophyte species, a native C3 and an invasive C4, from
two different salt marshes within Tagus Estuary, in which one, the soil, is heavy metal contaminated, in
order to allow the understanding of a heavy metal cross-tolerance to various induced abiotic stresses.
According to the IPCC 5th Assessment Report, all scenarios predict a rise in the surface
temperature over this century, as well as a very likely increase in the frequency and duration of heat
wave, with great significance in the Tagus Estuary region (Guerreiro et al., 2018), inevitably affecting
the marsh plant communities. Although negative stress signs were exhibited, both halophyte species
presented highly efficient tolerance mechanisms to heat stress, nevertheless it was evident an
intraspecific variation in the biophysiological and biochemical responses between both the C3 H.
portulacoides and C4 S. patens populations. Our data suggests that, when exposed to warming treatment,
H. portulacoides from the heavy metal contaminated location had a more efficient tolerance mechanism
and a higher resistance to warming stress when compared to plants from the non-contaminated site. This
was clearly displayed through the more efficient photobiological light harvesting processes found in the
pre-conditioned H. portulacoides, as well as the lower photoprotection observed in the non-pre-
conditioned H. portulacoides. On the other hand, in S. patens, the population from the non-contaminated
82
marsh appear to exhibit less damage than the population from the contaminated marsh, evident by the
photo-oxidative stress vulnerability experienced by pre-conditioned S. patens. Thus, cross-tolerance
results indicate that pre-conditioned H. portulacoides and non-pre-conditioned S. patens are better suited
to endure upcoming warming events than their counterparts. From this it seems reasonable to assume
that in heavy metal contaminated marsh, the non-indigenous S. patens will suffer more severe
consequences, while on the other hand H. portulacoides will display better performance under the same
heat conditions, which can dissuade the invasion trend showed by the S. patens in Tagus marshes,
favoring the indigenous community. Oppositely in non-contaminated marshes environmental changes
will make these ecosystems prone to the invasion by this exotic species. Therefore, it can be concluded
that the upcoming warming events boosted by climate change, will have a more serious and immediate
ecological consequences in marsh from the non-contaminated location due to the relative enabling of
the colonization by invasive species in the non-contaminated location, changing the marsh landscape in
a different and possibly more negative manner, than in the heavy metal contaminated marsh.
Climate change research also foresees the likely increase of the ongoing word-wide land
salinization phenomenon (IPCC, 2014). Coastal regions, especially in estuaries, will experience a soil
and water salinity increase at an elevated rate, due to sea level rise, storm and tidal surges coupled with
increases in air temperature (Dasgupta and Hossain et al., 2015). Moreover, it is expected that Tagus
estuary will significantly change in salinity concentrations and distribution (Rodrigues et al., 2016). This
phenomenon will bring profound consequences to the halophyte marsh communities, since salinity
concentration is one of the major constraints to species frequency, distribution and zonation in salt
marshes (Silvestri et al., 2004; Duarte et al, 2014b). To understand the pre-conditioning implications in
the salt tolerance mechanisms of this plants and their variability, biophysical and biochemical responses
to this potential stressor were uncovered. Our study showed a complex and significant intraspecific
variations in the H. portulacoides and S. patens salt stress responses due to their pre-conditioned
histories, our results suggest that heavy metal pre-conditioning does not have a straightforward influence
in the salinity tolerance mechanisms. Heavy metal pre-conditioned H. portulacoides, when compared to
their counterpart, presented a more deficient photochemical energy production and overall worse
performance when exposed to mild salinity, while under elevated exposure exhibited a better efficiency
in salt tolerance mechanisms. Nonetheless, heavy metal pre-conditioned S. patens shown a higher fitness
throughout increasing salt concentrations, displaying more effective LHC and dissipation mechanisms
than non-pre-conditioned individuals. Therefore, it can be argued that under mild salinities the
contaminated marsh may experience more severe ecological consequences, as result of the contrastingly
poorer performance from this H. portulacoides population, allowing an accelerated spreading of
invasive species, with impacts in the salt marsh biodiversity and organization. Nevertheless, elevated
salinities, both C3 and C4 heavy metal pre-conditioned marsh plants populations exhibit better fitness
than their counterparts, revealing that in this salt marsh there is a potentially higher salinity resistance,
favoring contaminated marsh growing and survival, according to imminent climate change
consequences.
Through this work it is possible to conclude that salt marsh halophyte species tolerance and
resilience to new abiotic factors is meaningfully influenced by their pre-conditioning history. This
reinforces the fact that plants, with a large abiotic tolerance spectrum, have an active physiological
plasticity according to their environmental specificity. This represents a tailored adaptation to the
stresses present in their specific habitat, as a result of cross-tolerance, that will have significant effects
in how plants’ mechanisms will act and respond to upcoming abiotic stresses, thus determining plant
growth and development. It is clear that halophytes’ adaptation to the local conditions or pre-
conditioning will indirectly influence, the way the population will react to climate changes, thereby,
influencing the salt marsh vegetation community and their ecosystem. Thus, it is far evident that
halotolerance and thermotolerance of the previously studied plants that are clearly interconnected with
83
their pre-conditioning, presenting an intraspecific physiological variation with ecological sway, in how
two neighboring salt marshes will evolve. Consequently, this key factor needs to be taken in to account
when modeling and predicting climate change scenarios on individual salt marshes. The first steps in
understanding pre-conditioning influence was taken by researching metal induced cross-tolerance to
thermal and saline stresses, relying on a multidisciplinary approach, considering and correlating
biochemical and biophysical responses and searching for ecology meaning. This examination took after
this premise and contributed with pertinent new information to the comprehension of ecophysiological
drivers. This can also be a tool useful to more efficiently manage appropriate conservation actions,
highlighting the services of all salt marshes in order to be able to benefit from their unique and valuable
resources in the future. Additionally, among these strategies, the heterogeneity between salt marsh
habitats should also be protected to maintain intraspecific variability safeguarding a variety of
physiological specializations that will, in some instances, result in an advantageous cross-tolerance.
